questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
Memory cells belong to adaptive immunity, as they store pathogen-specific responses for future encounters.

Why not other options:-

  • a) Dendritic cells: Part of innate immunity; they detect pathogens and present antigens to adaptive immune cells.
  • b) Epithelia of skin: Acts as a physical and chemical barrier, crucial for innate immunity.
  • d) Plasma proteins: Includes complement proteins, which directly attack pathogens as part of innate immunity.

Key Takeaway: Innate immunity provides immediate, nonspecific defense through physical barriers (e.g., skin), immune cells (e.g., dendritic cells), and plasma proteins (e.g., complement system). Adaptive immunity, in contrast, is slower but specific and involves memory cells, which enable long-term immunity and faster responses to repeated exposures.

choices.text: A- II, B- IV, C- I, D- II
A- III, B -II, C- I, D- IV
A- IV, B- I, C- II, D- III
A- II, B- III, C- IV, D- I

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
1. Thymus derived lymphocytes (T cells) → III: Express antigen receptors
    • T cells express T-cell receptors (TCRs) to recognize antigens.
  2. Dendritic cells → II: Capture microbes & display them to lymphocytes
    • Dendritic cells act as antigen-presenting cells (APCs).
  3. Bone marrow derived lymphocytes (B cells) → IV: Express membrane-bound antibodies
    • B cells have surface-bound immunoglobulins as antigen receptors.
  4. Natural killer (NK) cells → I: Destroy infected cells
    • NK cells target virus-infected and tumor cells for destruction.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • Option a) A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-II
    • A-II: Incorrect, T cells do not primarily capture microbes; they express antigen receptors (III).
    • B-IV: Incorrect, dendritic cells do not express membrane-bound antibodies; they present antigens (II).
    • C-I: Incorrect, B cells do not destroy infected cells; they express membrane-bound antibodies (IV).
    • D-II: Incorrect, NK cells do not capture microbes; they destroy infected cells (I).
  • Option c) A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
    • A-IV: Incorrect, T cells do not express membrane-bound antibodies; they express antigen receptors (III).
    • B-I: Incorrect, dendritic cells do not destroy infected cells; they capture and display antigens (II).
    • C-II: Incorrect, B cells do not capture microbes; they express antibodies (IV).
    • D-III: Incorrect, NK cells do not express antigen receptors; they destroy infected cells (I).
  • Option d) A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
    • A-II: Incorrect, T cells do not capture microbes; they express antigen receptors (III).
    • B-III: Incorrect, dendritic cells do not express antigen receptors; they present antigens (II).
    • C-IV: Correct, B cells express membrane-bound antibodies.
    • D-I: Correct, NK cells destroy infected cells.

Key Takeaway:

  • T cells → Express antigen receptors.
  • B cells → Express membrane-bound antibodies.
  • Dendritic cells → Present antigens to lymphocytes.
  • NK cells → Destroy infected or abnormal cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of inflammosome?
questions.solution:
NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are cytosolic receptors named after the founding member NOD-2. They recognize a wide variety of substances, including products released from necrotic or damaged cells (e.g., uric acid and adenosine triphosphate [ATP]), loss of intracellular K+ ions, and some microbial products. NOD like receptor (NLRs) signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the INFLAMMASOME, which activates an enzyme (caspase-1) that cleaves a precursor form of the cytokine interleukin-1 (IL-1) to generate the biologically active form. Caspase 1 is a critical component of the inflammasome, responsible for activating pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β and IL-18.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • a) Caspase 9: Involved in the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, not the inflammasome.
  • c) Caspase 3: Plays a role in apoptosis execution, not directly linked to the inflammasome.
  • d) All of the above: Incorrect because only Caspase 1 is a component of the inflammasome.

Key Takeaways: Inflammasomes are multiprotein complexes that play a crucial role in the innate immune response by activating inflammatory caspases, specifically Caspase 1. Caspase 1 is involved in the processing of pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1β and IL-18, which are key players in inflammation. Caspase 9 and Caspase 3 are involved in apoptosis, not the inflammasome.

questions.text: Cytokines produced by T Helper cell type 1 is?
questions.solution:
T Helper cell type 1 (Th1) produces Interferon gamma (IFN-γ), a cytokine that plays a crucial role in cell-mediated immunity by activating macrophages and promoting the inflammatory response, especially in the defense against intracellular pathogens like viruses and some bacteria.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:

  • A) IL-4: Produced by T Helper cell type 2 (Th2), involved in allergic responses and promoting antibody production.
  • B) IL-17: Produced by T Helper cell type 17 (Th17), important for inflammation and defense against fungal and extracellular bacterial infections.
  • D) IL-5: Produced by Th2 cells, involved in eosinophil activation and response to parasitic infections.

Key Takeaways: · Th1 → IFN-γ (cell-mediated immunity)

  • Th2 → IL-4, IL-5, IL-13. (humoral immunity, allergies)
  • Th17 → IL-17 (inflammation, extracellular defense)

questions.text: Granuloma formation is seen in which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Granuloma formation is a hallmark of Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH). This type of immune response is mediated by T cells, specifically CD4+ T-helper cells. It occurs in response to chronic infections or foreign antigens that the immune system is unable to eliminate, leading to the formation of granulomas as a defense mechanism.

Example: Granulomas are commonly seen in diseases such as tuberculosis (TB), where macrophages and T cells form a protective barrier around an infecting pathogen that cannot be cleared.

  • Type I hypersensitivity: Immediate hypersensitivity (e.g., allergic reactions like hay fever, anaphylaxis), mediated by IgE
  • Type II hypersensitivity: Cytotoxic reactions (e.g., autoimmune hemolytic anemia), mediated by IgG/IgM antibodies against cells or tissues.
  • Type III hypersensitivity: Immune complex-mediated reactions (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis), where immune complexes deposit in tissues and cause inflammation.

Key Takeaways: Granulomas are a defining feature of Type IV hypersensitivity, distinguishing it from the other types.

questions.text: All are the mast cell mediators, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF) is primarily produced by macrophages, monocytes, and T cells, not mast cells. It is a key pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in systemic inflammation, immune regulation, and the pathogenesis of various diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and sepsis. While TNF plays a crucial role in immune responses, it is not one of the mediators released by mast cells during allergic reactions.

Why the other options are incorrect:-

  • A) Prostaglandin D2 → This is the most abundant mediator Produced in mast cells by the cyclooxygenase pathway. It causes intense bronchospasm and increases mucus secretion.
  • C) Leukotrienes → Leukotrienes C4 And D4 are the most potent Vasoactive and spasmogenic agents. On a molar basis, they are several thousand times more active than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Leukotriene B4 Is highly chemotactic for neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes.
  • D) Platelet-activating factor (PAF) → PAF is a lipid mediator produced by some mast cell populations that is not derived from arachidonic acid. It causes platelet aggregation, histamine release, bronchospasm, increased vascular permeability, and vasodilation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mast cell mediators include Prostaglandin D2, Platelet Activating Factor (PAF), and Leukotriene C4, all of which are involved in inflammation and allergic responses.
  • TNF, while crucial in systemic inflammation, is not a mast cell mediator, as it is primarily produced by macrophages and other immune cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is a morphological manifestation of immune complex injury from the following?
questions.solution:
• Fibrinoid necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration are characteristic features of immune complex-mediated injury (Type III hypersensitivity). When immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in tissues, they can activate the complement system, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
    • Fibrinoid necrosis refers to the deposition of immune complexes along with fibrin in blood vessel walls or tissue, causing a characteristic appearance of pink, homogenous material under a microscope.
    • Neutrophilic infiltration occurs as neutrophils are recruited to the site of immune complex deposition, where they release enzymes and inflammatory mediators, contributing to tissue damage.

Why the other options are incorrect:-

  • b) Lymphocytic infiltration & Caseous necrosis:
  • Lymphocytic infiltration and caseous necrosis are more commonly associated with granulomatous inflammation (Type IV hypersensitivity), such as in tuberculosis or chronic infections, not immune complex-mediated injury.
  • c) Coagulative necrosis & Lymphocytic infiltration:
  • Coagulative necrosis is typically seen in ischemic injury (e.g., myocardial infarction), where tissue death is caused by a lack of blood supply, not immune complex deposition. Lymphocytic infiltration is more characteristic of chronic inflammation, such as in viral infections or autoimmune diseases, rather than acute immune complex injury.
  • d) None of the above:
  • This option is incorrect because Fibrinoid necrosis & Neutrophilic infiltration (choice a) is the correct morphological manifestation of immune complex injury.

Key Takeaways: The combination of fibrinoid necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration is the hallmark morphological feature of immune complex-mediated injury (Type III hypersensitivity).

questions.text: CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into___
questions.solution:
Cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV)

Cytokine-mediated inflammation:

  • CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 effector cells.
  • Subsequent exposure to the antigen results in the secretion of cytokines. IFN-γ activates macrophages to produce substances that cause tissue damage and promote fibrosis, and IL-17 and other cytokines recruit leukocytes, thus promoting inflammation.
  • The classical T cell-mediated inflammatory reaction is Delayed type of hypersensitivity reaction (DTH)

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • b) Th17 & Th22 effector cells:
    • Th17 cells are involved in inflammation and the defense against fungi and extracellular bacteria. Th22 cells also contribute to skin and mucosal immunity. However, these subsets typically arise in response to specific cytokines such as IL-6 and TGF-β, not primarily from exposure to protein antigens.
  • c) Th1 & Th17 effector cells:
    • Th17 cells are involved in inflammatory responses and immune defense, but they are not typically the primary effector cells differentiated from CD4+ T cells in response to protein antigens. This combination is not the most common differentiation pathway in response to antigen exposure.
  • d) Th10 & Th22 effector cells:
    • Th10 cells are a less common subset that produces IL-10, an anti-inflammatory cytokine. Th22 cells are involved in skin immunity. Both of these subsets are not typically the main effector cells generated from the exposure of CD4+ T cells to protein antigens.

Key Takeaway: When CD4+ T cells are exposed to protein antigens, they typically differentiate into Th1 and Th2 effector cells, which play central roles in cell-mediated immunity and humoral immunity, respectively. This differentiation is guided by the specific cytokines present in the immune microenvironment.

choices.text: IgM or IgG antibodies attach to the antigen to form an immune complex
Cytotoxic T cells recognizing target antigen and kill these cells
IgE attaches to mast cells release mediators and cause vascular reaction

questions.text: A lady has come to clinic with chief complaints of rash, knee joint pain, fever and cervical lymphadenopathy since 3-4 days. She gave history of taking influenza vaccine 5 days ago. Her urine report showed protein ++. Which of the following is the correct aetiology for her condition?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described in the question-rash, joint pain, fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and proteinuria-are consistent with a condition called serum sickness, which is a type of immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity (Type III). Serum sickness typically occurs after exposure to foreign proteins, such as a vaccine or medication, and involves the formation of immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes). These immune complexes deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and damage.

  • IgM or IgG antibodies bind to the foreign antigen, form immune complexes, and deposit in various tissues like the kidneys (causing proteinuria), joints (leading to arthralgia), and skin (causing a rash). This leads to a systemic inflammatory response.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • b) Cytotoxic T cells recognizing target antigen and killing these cells:
    • This mechanism describes Type II hypersensitivity, where cytotoxic T cells or antibodies (like IgG or IgM) directly attack and kill cells. This is seen in conditions like autoimmune hemolytic anemia or Goodpasture syndrome, but it does not apply to the symptoms described in the question, which are more consistent with immune complex formation rather than direct cell destruction.
  • c) IgE attaches to mast cells, releasing mediators and causing vascular reactions:
    • This describes Type I hypersensitivity (immediate hypersensitivity), where IgE antibodies mediate allergic reactions, such as anaphylaxis, hay fever, or asthma. These reactions involve mast cell degranulation, but the patient's symptoms (rash, joint pain, fever, proteinuria) are not typical of an immediate allergic response. The condition described here is likely due to immune complex deposition, not an IgE-mediated reaction.
  • d) Increased serum C3 levels:
    • C3 is a complement protein involved in the immune response. In Type III hypersensitivity (immune complex disease), complement activation occurs, but C3 levels are typically decreased as the complement system is consumed in the formation of immune complexes, not increased. So, increased C3 is not consistent with the clinical presentation of immune complex-mediated disease.

Key Takeaway:

The correct etiology for this patient's condition is immune complex formation, a feature of Type III hypersensitivity. The immune complexes form when IgM or IgG antibodies bind to foreign antigens (like the influenza vaccine) and deposit in tissues, causing symptoms like rash, joint pain, fever, lymphadenopathy, and proteinuria. This is commonly referred to as serum sickness.

questions.text: Which of the following systemic autoimmune disease is not mediated by T cells?
questions.solution:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is primarily an autoimmune disease mediated by antibodies rather than T cells. It involves the production of autoantibodies (such as antinuclear antibodies - ANA), which target the body's own tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. SLE is considered a Type III hypersensitivity reaction, driven by the formation of immune complexes, which can deposit in various tissues (like the kidneys, joints, and skin) and trigger inflammation. Although T cells do play a role in disease progression, SLE is primarily antibody-mediated.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • a) Rheumatoid arthritis (RA):
    • RA is a systemic autoimmune disease that is primarily T cell-mediated. It involves T cell activation that triggers an inflammatory response in the joints, leading to the formation of rheumatoid factor and other antibodies that contribute to tissue damage and inflammation. The disease is also associated with the activation of synovial macrophages and the formation of pannus, which destroys joint tissue.
  • b) Systemic sclerosis (SSc):
    • Systemic sclerosis (SSc), also known as scleroderma, is another T cell-mediated autoimmune disorder. It involves dysregulated T cell activation, leading to the production of fibroblasts and excessive collagen deposition in tissues. This results in skin thickening and fibrosis in various organs, including the lungs and heart. T cells are central in initiating the fibrosis process.
  • d) Sjogren syndrome:
    • Sjogren syndrome is an autoimmune disease where T cells mediate inflammation in exocrine glands (such as the salivary and lacrimal glands). The disease leads to dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), and T cells play a central role in the destruction of these glands.

Key Takeaway:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is the exception in this list because it is primarily antibody-mediated, with autoantibodies causing immune complex formation and tissue damage, rather than being directly mediated by T cells like the other listed autoimmune diseases (RA, SSc, and Sjogren syndrome), which are more T cell-driven.

choices.text: A- II, B- I, C- III
A- I, B- III, C- II
A- III, B- II, C- I

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
• Polymorphisms in PTPN22 gene →
    • Encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase
    • Associated with rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes, and several other autoimmune diseases.
    • PTPN22 is the non-HLA gene that is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.
    • The phosphatase functionally defective phosphatase → unable to dampen the activity of tyrosine kinases that are involved in many responses of lymphocytes → excessive lymphocyte activation.
  • Polymorphisms in NOD2 gene →
  • Associated with Crohn disease, a form of inflammatory bowel disease,
  • NOD2, a member of the NOD-like receptor (NLR) family (discussed earlier), is a cytoplasmic sensor of microbes that is expressed in intestinal epithelial and other cells. According to one hypothesis, the disease-associated variant is ineffective at sensing gut microbes, including commensal bacteria, resulting in entry of and chronic inflammatory responses against these normally well-tolerated organism
  • Polymorphisms in IL-2 receptor (CD25) gene →
  • Associated with multiple sclerosis and other autoimmune diseases. These variants may influence the expression and activity of this key receptor and thereby affect the balance between regulatory and effector T cells

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: A- IV, B- III, C- I, D-II
A- IIII, B- I, C- II, D- IV
A- II, B- IV, C- III, D- I
A- III, B- I, C- IV, D- II

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
Image A → Centromeric pattern

Image B → Homogenous pattern

Image C → Nucleolar pattern

Image D → Speckled pattern

  • Centromeric pattern → Patients with systemic sclerosis often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.
  • Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining → reflects antibodies to chromatin, histones, and, occasionally, double-stranded DNA.
  • Speckled pattern → the presence of uniform or variable-sized speckles. This is one of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence and therefore the least specific. It reflects the presence of antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
  • Nucleolar pattern refers to the presence of a few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. This pattern is reported most often in patients with systemic sclerosis

Key Takeaway:

  • Centromere = Systemic Sclerosis (only centromere-specific)
  • Homogeneous = Chromatin/DNA (mainly SLE)
  • Speckled = Non-DNA Antigens (like SLE, Sjögren's)
  • Nucleolar = RNA (linked to Systemic Sclerosis)

choices.text: Plasma cells are absent throughout the body
Germinal centers of the lymph nodes are underdeveloped
B cells are markedly decreased in circulation

questions.text: Regarding beta agammaglobulinemia all are true, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton's agammaglobulinemia)

  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia is characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B cells and pre-B cells) to develop into mature B cells
  • Exclusively in males
  • Become apparent after 6 months of age, as maternal immunoglobulins are depleted.
  • Recurrent bacterial infections of the respiratory tract, such as acute and chronic pharyngitis, sinusitis, otitis media, bronchitis, and pneumonia
  • Almost always the causative organisms -
    • Haemophilus influenzae
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Staphylococcus aureus.
  • These organisms are normally opsonized by antibodies and cleared by phagocytosis. Because antibodies are important for neutralizing infectious viruses, individuals with this disease are also susceptible to certain viral infections, especially those caused by enteroviruses, such as echovirus, poliovirus, and coxsackievirus.
  • The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:
    • B cells are absent or markedly decreased in the circulation, and serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins are depressed. Pre-B cells, which express the B-lineage marker CD19 but not membrane Ig, are found in normal numbers in the bone marrow.
    • Germinal centers of lymph nodes, Peyer patches, the appendix, and tonsils are underdeveloped.
    • Plasma cells are absent throughout the body.
    • T cell-mediated reactions are normal.
  • Treatment :- replacement therapy with immunoglobulins.
  • Prophylactic IVIG therapy allows most individuals to reach adulthood.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • b) Plasma cells are absent throughout the body:
    • In beta agammaglobulinemia, plasma cells (which are differentiated B cells) are absent because there is a failure in B cell maturation, preventing plasma cell formation. This is a hallmark of the condition.
  • c) Germinal centers of the lymph nodes are underdeveloped:
    • Germinal centers are structures in lymph nodes where B cells mature and produce antibodies. Since B cells are absent or severely reduced in beta agammaglobulinemia, germinal centers are underdeveloped or absent.
  • d) B cells are markedly decreased in circulation:
    • This is a key feature of beta agammaglobulinemia. There is a severe reduction or absence of B cells in circulation due to the mutation in the BTK gene, which is essential for B cell development.

Key Takeaway:

  • Beta agammaglobulinemia is a B cell deficiency disorder characterized by absent or markedly reduced B cells and plasma cells, with underdeveloped germinal centers. T-cell functions remain normal, which helps differentiate it from other immunodeficiencies.

questions.text: Aβ - major fibril protein is associated with which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Aβ (Amyloid-beta) is the major fibril protein involved in Alzheimer's disease (AD). In AD, amyloid-beta plaques accumulate in the brain, particularly between nerve cells, contributing to neuronal damage and cognitive decline. These plaques are a hallmark of Alzheimer's pathology and are primarily composed of amyloid-beta peptides, which are derived from a larger protein called amyloid precursor protein (APP). The deposition of these plaques disrupts normal brain function, leading to the symptoms of Alzheimer's.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

  • a) Multiple myeloma:
    • Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that involves the overproduction of abnormal plasma cells. The fibril proteins associated with amyloidosis in multiple myeloma are light chains (not amyloid-beta). This results in the deposition of amyloid light chain (AL) amyloidosis, not amyloid-beta.
  • c) Type II diabetes:
    • Type II diabetes is a metabolic disorder characterized by insulin resistance and impaired glucose metabolism. While amyloid deposits are found in the pancreas in some individuals with Type II diabetes, these deposits are primarily composed of islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP), not amyloid-beta.
  • d) Familial Mediterranean fever:
    • Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autosomal recessive condition that leads to recurrent episodes of fever and inflammation, often affecting the peritoneum, pleura, and joints. It is due to mutations in the MEFV gene, which encodes the pyrin protein. Amyloid deposits in FMF are typically composed of AA amyloid, not amyloid-beta.

Key Takeaway:

  • Amyloid-beta (Aβ) is specifically associated with Alzheimer's disease. In this condition, amyloid plaques formed by amyloid-beta peptides accumulate in the brain, leading to neuronal damage. Other conditions, like multiple myeloma, type II diabetes, and familial Mediterranean fever, are associated with different types of amyloid fibrils, such as AL amyloid, IAPP, and AA amyloid, respectively.

questions.text: The following lymphomas can occur in individuals with AIDS, except:
questions.solution:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of leukemia characterized by the gradual accumulation of mature, but functionally impaired B lymphocytes. It is generally a disease of older adults and is not typically associated with AIDS or HIV infection. In fact, CLL does not show a significantly increased incidence in HIV-infected individuals. It is a more indolent form of leukemia and has a distinct pathophysiology compared to lymphomas associated with HIV.

Explanation for Incorrect Answers:

Lymphomas in individuals with AIDS:

5% of AIDS patients present with lymphoma, and approximately another 5% develop lymphoma during their subsequent course, virtually all of which originate from transformed B cells.

With effective ART, the incidence of lymphoma has fallen

the association of lymphoma and HIV infection is only partially explained by T-cell immunodeficiency. Indeed, based on molecular characterization of HIV-associated lymphomas and these epidemiologic considerations, at least two mechanisms appear to underlie

the increased risk of B-cell tumors in HIV-infected individuals is because of 2 mechanisms:-

  1. Unchecked proliferation of B cells infected with oncogenic herpesviruses in the setting of profound T cell depletion (AIDS).
    • Burkitt lymphoma
    • Large B cell lymphoma
  2. T-cell immunity is required to restrain the proliferation of B cells infected with oncogenic viruses such as EBV and HHV8. With the appearance of severe T-cell depletion late in the course of HIV infection, this control is lost. As a result, AIDS patients are at high risk of developing aggressive B cell lymphomas composed of tumor cells infected by oncogenic viruses, particularly EBV.
    • EBV+ large cell lymphoma
    • HHV8+ Primary effusion lymphoma
    • EBV+ Hodgkin lymphoma

Key Takeaway:

AIDS is associated with an increased risk of various lymphomas, particularly Burkitt lymphoma, large B-cell lymphoma, and Hodgkin lymphoma, primarily due to immunosuppression and the reactivation of EBV. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), however, is not typically linked to HIV/AIDS and does not show an increased prevalence in this population.
